column3: between the river [[Gilrain]] to the east and [[Dol Amroth]] to the west. To the north was the river [[Ringló]]. The location is not mentioned in ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''.

column1: Tarnost does not appear in the close-up map of Gondor in ''[[The Return of the King]]''.<ref>{{RK|Map}}</ref> The first reference is in ''[[The War of the Ring]]'': In the Western map section there is a dot visible in square Q12 at the northern tip of the hills south of the Ringló
column2: and the text states that it had a penciled note calling it ''Tarnost''.<ref>{{WR|3|XIV}}
column3: p. 437</ref> The second reference appears in ''[[Sauron Defeated]]'': In a manuscript Tolkien stated that "From [[Erech]] a road ran by [the] sea
column4: skirting in a loop the '''hills of Tarnost'''
column5: and so to [[Ethir Anduin]] and the [[Lebennin]].".<ref>{{SD|Ir}}

column1: [[Wayne G. Hammond|Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull|Scull]] suggest that ''Tarnost'' appears to be an earlier name for ''[[Ethring]]''
column2: as they share a "similar position on the published map".<ref>{{HM|AoL}}

column1: Tarnost also appears on the map of the [[White Mountains]] in ''[[The Atlas of Middle-earth]]''
column2: identified by [[Karen Wynn Fonstad|Wynn Fonstad]] as a city<!-- Is Fonstad the source for the notion of a city? (User:Morgan) -->. The nearby hills are also named as the Hills of Tarnost.<ref>[[Karen Wynn Fonstad]]

column1: It has been suggested that ''Tarnost'' is a [[Noldorin]] name
column2: the second element perhaps being ''[[ost]]'' ("city").<ref>{{webcite|author=Paul Strack|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-1420740361.html|articlename=N. ''Tarnost'' loc.|dated=1 April 2016|website=[http://eldamo.org/index.html Eldamo - An Elvish Lexicon]|accessed=26 September 2016}}</ref>
